Award.AwardTitle: Mechbio Symposium: Finding the Pieces, Building the Puzzle; University of California-San Diego; La Jolla, California; August 4-5, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Mechbio Symposium: Finding the Pieces, Building the Puzzle; University of California, San Diego; August 4-5, 2016" will be a forum where theorists, computational scientists, and experimentalists from both the STEM disciplines and the Life Sciences can begin a conversation about integrating different disciplines and methodologies to advance the field of quantitative multiscale mechanobiology. In order to have a cross-sectional representation of these fields, at least 40-50 participants will attend. This number will allow the different disciplines to be well-represented, without being overwhelmingly large. There are many annual societies with meetings on broad themes, but this meeting will focus on the theme of mechanics in biology across the different scales from cells to tissues to organs. In addition to platform talks and poster sessions, the meeting will also foster collaborative efforts and potential partnerships between mentors and mentees. Break out sessions throughout the meeting with small groups will be given the task of laying out a list of specific aims to answer the question "How would you put together a cell's/tissue/organ mechanome"? By engaging an audience across different career levels, and by disseminating the conference program to a larger audience as a journal report, this symposium will enable us to highlight the importance of mechanics at the organ, tissue, and cellular level. The organizers will actively recruit speakers and participants at different career stages, gender, and underrepresented minorities.

The focus of the Symposium on mechanobiology and fostering collaboration among the multiple disciplines is of direct interest to the goals of the Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The inaugural MechBio symposium hosted at the University of California San Diego was a huge success. Spanning over two days and six sessions, we had nearly 70 participants, ranging from graduate students to full professors. The symposium was held in a single session, with ample time for discussion and opportunities for initiating collaboration. Because of generous support from the NSF BMMB program, we were able to conduct this symposium without charging any registration fees from the participants. We believe that this was an important factor in making this interdisciplinary meeting accessible. Additionally, we were able to support participants through 9 travel awards, 1 child care award, 2 poster awards. Our keynote speakers are all leaders in mechanobiology, including one international speaker (Prof. Madan Rao from NCBS, India). The session topics ranged from single cell mechanobiology to tissue and organism level effects.

 

We conducted a short survey on the second day of the symposium to obtain feedback. Overall, the symposium was very well received and the responses are summarized in the table below. Some highlights from post meeting email responses include

 

“Many thanks for a truly amazing conference a couple of weeks ago. It was a fantastic collection of diverse and high-quality talks. It was also wonderful to know what a vibrant community of mechanobiology researchers we have in our neighborhood. I hope we can continue to have similar meetings in the future. I'd be interested in helping organize sometime, in case you are looking for people.”

 

“I am definitely interested in making this MechBio meeting a regular thing. I am not sure how to get started but let me know if you want to figure this out (mostly with a lot of guidance from this years organizers). It was indeed a wonderful meeting. Thank you all for the efforts.”


Based on this feedback, we propose to conduct this event again in 2 years (summer of 2018).

 



Last Modified: 02/03/2017
Modified by: Padmini Rangamani
